history.content: LOL this should be called "Battle of the Trolls" - OP and Thomas Liao

1. This is an automatic endorsement. Here is the discussion explaining the endorsed student answers @5842

2. There was a "who is steven bi" post somewhere in this piazza lol @5661

This is an automatic endorsement. Here is the discussion explaining the endorsed student answers @5842

From my understanding, this is an automatic endorsement. This has occurred even retroactively on old piazzas, I remember an instructor posted this a while back in one of the piazza discussion posts. Here is the discussion explaining the endorsed student answers @5842
From my understanding, this is an automatic endorsement. This has occurred even retroactively on old piazzas, I remember an instructor posted this a while back in one of the piazza discussion posts.

children.subject:
First of all, no one is targetting Steven Bi. He is certainly a very helpful person. 

Second of all, I know many "non course volunteers" are former TAs. If they would like to become a TA again, I would love to see them answer on Piazza. But if they are not part of the course, they should not be on the Piazza. The Piazza is not for them. It is only for people currently in the course. It doesn't matter how qualified they are.

Anon - you don't understand why Piazza exists. The primary purpose of Piazza is not just for students to answer questions, but also to get answers. Otherwise, why not hide the answer for everybody except the initial answerer and asker, such that everybody who is not the initial answerer nor the asker answers the question as well?
I am not the right person to ask why Piazza is designed like that. However, it certainly would cause students to repeat the same questions. So making the question and answer to all is usually better.
This seems like a non issue. Checking out Steven Bi's profile https://piazza.com/careers/dashboard#/my_profile/h69mwtr4j7461h many of the piazza's he's a part of he was a TA.
Also, in general, if you feel like you have something to contribute on piazza, you don't have to hold back simply because someone else already contributed.

On the surface, it seems like non-course volunteers contribute to the course. After all, more Piazza questions get answered! However, students and course staff actually learn LESS.

If a question has already been answered fully, are you going to repeat the same thing? No. And that process of answering other people's questions is crucial for TAs and students alike to fill in gaps in their understanding.

If you are not in the course, you should not be in the Piazza. The Piazza is not for you. Period.

Anon - You have made a few unsubstantiated claims.

  • Why is the primary purpose of course staff to learn? Perhaps some TAs teach to pay their tuition, or because they enjoy teaching. If TAs teach for other reasons than to learn, then your claim that non-enrolled non-TAs should not answer questions because it deprives TAs of education falls apart. 
  • Why do you assume that a fully-answered question will not be repeated? A cursory glance of this Piazza will demonstrate that even the most fully answered questions are repeatedly asked. If foundational questions are repeatedly asked, then non-enrolled non-TAs answering a fraction of instances of those questions will not deprive enrolled / TAs of education.
  • Why do you assume that questions are fully answered? Often an initial answer requires additional clarification or substantiation (such as your previous comment). If there is always room to add knowledge, then non-enrolled non-TAs incompletely answering questions would not substantially deprive enrolled / TAs of education.
  • Why do you assume that people are either enrolled, non-enrolled, or active TAs? Sometimes people audit classes. Should they not be able to answer questions either?
  • Why is answering questions a necessary avenue for education? You repeatedly assert that answering questions helps people learn. Presumably, so does going to lecture, discussion, or lab. Why is answering questions on Piazza so necessary an avenue for education you would force non-enrolled non-TAs to leave the course Piazza (and depriving people of answers)?
  • Why is Piazza a necessary means of answering questions? People can answer questions on Yahoo Answers or Quora. Less facetiously, they can also help out in guerilla sections or office hours.

Good points.

However, Piazza is only for students and course staff.

"Non-course volunteers", etc should be banned.

I've only taken one class in which Steven Bi posted on the course piazza, and I'll admit that I have at times been bothered by some ways in which he has approached answering things, but overall I felt like if he weren't answering things a lot of things would have gone unanswered. Also, I have at times gotten completely incorrect advice from students on piazza, and I didn't always learn it was wrong until I lost points over it, so I'm really not going to complain about more eyeballs from people who know what they are talking about. It's not entirely clear to me how the OP thinks people like Steven are "diminishing students' learning experience".

I kind of doubt that. There are lots of course staff for these courses, and not too much piazza activity. Maybe 1000 notes over a semester, divided between 20 TAs means about 50 notes per TA, which is 3 or 4 answers a week.
That is not really a fair measure since there is a huge influx right before midterms and finals

Currently, there's no incentive for TAs to answer questions on Piazza.

It's something they do on the side to help students, since they're good people.

If an incentive was created, or if TAs were required to answer X (a small # of questions) per week, then there would be no need for "volunteers"
That would only provide more problems. Currently, piazza stats are counted by contributions and quantity would be emphasized over quality.

That's a solution I thought of on the fly. Clearly, better solutions exist.

My point is, we shouldn't need to and we don't need to rely on "volunteers" to do the job of paid course staff. It doesn't just hurt student's learning, but it's also unethical
this just sounds like a hate post at this point...

LOL. I am very grateful for volunteers when they don't detract from students' learning.

For example, on EECS 101 Piazza, or Facebook, or Slack, or in homework parties, etc.

I specifically said - "I know they're trying to help out, and I am really glad for that - don't get me wrong."

I love and appreciate the work they are doing. And they are trying to help. I am just telling them - it's not helping.

Anon - your logic is incoherent. What is the difference between a volunteer answering a question in homework party versus on Piazza? Wouldn't they still be depriving a student of the opportunity to answer questions?
Yep!
I strongly disagree. Without Steven Bi, many of the questions that I and many had on various piazzas (188, 70, 170) would go unanswered.

"In fact, by your reasoning, why would we even need TAs in our piazza page?" I am also wondering this. Steven just seems like an extra bonus TA. This is especially nice given how hard it is for course staff to answer everyone's questions. Sometimes when you're close to a deadline you just need a good answer that helps you understand the problem. So if Steven is an extra TA that seems like a good thing to me. 

And there are so many ways for people to learn or get help or discuss outside piazza.

The EECS department has a fundamental problem if students need to rely on non-course "volunteers" to get help.

We have a few options - 

1) Incentivize TAs to answer more on Piazza

2) Incentivize students to answer more on Piazza

3) Hire more course staff.

If you are not in the course, you should not be in the Piazza. The Piazza is not for you. Period.

The EECS department may have a problem, but banning people who aren't in the class isn't going to solve it. It's just going to lead to unanswered questions. But I'd hesitate to even say that this is a sign that the EECS department has a problem. The department didn't suddenly get more funding just because Piazza was created, and I highly doubt the department is sitting on a pile of money that could be spent on professional piazza answerers. I feel like this crusade is looking a gift horse in the mouth. You should be more grateful that you're not in school a few years ago back when the people who had questions had no place to ask them.

I think it's incredibly selfish for these "volunteers" (not pointing you out specifically) to continue to answer prolifically on Piazza when it's clear it's hurting students' learning. And after this post clearly tells them that. If they really want to help, I would love for them to start unofficial review sessions or something - but continuing to post on Piazza is just wrong.

You have to understand that it doesn't seem like many people agree with you, so it's not fair to say "it's clear it's hurting students' learning". You also have to understand that you can't just give orders to people and then call them selfish for not obeying you.
Anon - where is your evidence that volunteers answering questions hurts students' learning? You have repeatedly asserted this claim without support.

Thomas, you are being a troll once again (see @5842).

EECS 101 is for serious discussions only.

I think it takes more than just a person to decide on a policy(^"let's ban it in course Piazzas, for everyone's learning"?!). I strongly disagree with you, as Steven Bi has helped tremendously in the course I took this semester. He was the person with the same experience and knowledge as other TAs who would reply to my question within a few minutes. He was the only reason why almost every cs70 posts were answered especially near the final when students would spam literally any question they have from past exams(he even had to deal with soo many duplicates) and keep in mind that other TAs have their finals too so most of them didn't have time to answer questions right away. Many students still participate in discussions and you are welcome to participate even in his presence. In fact, by your reasoning, why would we even need TAs in our piazza page? But I guess I do see some drawback with Steven's presence. He probably raises many exam means significantly just because of the sole amount of questions he had answered and corrected (disadvantageous because things you have spent so much time to understand are explained by him so simply and so clearly to everyone else in the class). Just check out the posts on cs70 notes. He would answer every question any student has, although I do have to acknowledge that due to his tremendous experience, his responses can sometimes make us feel diminished but I'm okay with that as it can be annoying at times to have to explain basic concepts that we should have learned on our own. You can safely ignore his responses if you feel like they are obstructive.

Answering questions on Piazza helps students find gaps in their understanding of the material.

Answering questions on Piazza helps TAs learn to explain material better and become better TAs.


Now, if someone is doing their job for them, then those students and TAs are being deprived of their learning.

The principle is simple - if you are not in the course, you should not be in the Piazza.

But Piazza is a place for members of a course to discuss. If someone is not in the course, and he is answering questions, then fewer people in the course are participating in the discussions, diminishing students' learning experience.

Please elaborate on this.
Obviously the OP is upset for a reason, even if some of us don't understand why. I don't think you should call their feelings ridiculous.
Yes you're right. I just hope that he doesn't look at the original question and think that his answers and volunteering aren't highly valued by many people

No one is targetting Steven Bi here. He is one of the most helpful people on any Piazza, period.

The principle is simple - if you are not in the course, you should not be in the Piazza.

Anon, I also have a simple principle - if you can answer a question on a course Piazza, you should answer it. 

 

Now, we have two principles, neither of which is substantiated. Which ought win?

 

You are making ill-posed appeals to teleology that don't address the reality of students' experiences. Sometimes questions linger unanswered indefinitely. Would it be better to allow such uncertainty to continue, or to - shock and horror - let somebody who is not enrolled in the course nor a TA answer it?

Thomas, you are being a troll once again (see @5842).

EECS 101 is for serious discussions only.
Stephen Bi is one of the most helpful people I have ever seen. This is ridiculous.

If former TAs really want to answer questions on Piazza, the staff should make it clear who they are and what their level of authority is in the course.

On this Piazza, several "instructor endorsed students" have answered questions incorrectly. Turns out they weren't peer advisors, but students believed them anyway since they were "instructor endorsed."
well people make mistakes, including students, past student, TAs, professors...

Any student who has answers endorsed by instructors gets a check mark. It might be a misleading check mark. If you disagree with the check marks, you should complain to Piazza for implementing them, but this is a separate issue.

None of us really know about the strange Piazza check mark situation, but the point stands - if former TAs are really interested in answering questions on Piazza, the staff should make it clear who they are and what level of authority they have.

I've been the TA mainly in charge of answering EE16A's piazza questions for a couple semesters, and I disagree - with classes this huge, questions would go unanswered without former students helping out (especially during crunch times like around MT2). It's kind of overwhelming at times, so I'm super grateful for any help, whether that be from current students or past ones.

For 16A at least, the past students who answer questions were/are mostly TAs, so there's no issue in quality of answers.

I absolutely agree. We also have many other resources, who are members of the course - fellow students, tutors, TAs, and professors.

The principle is simple - if you are not in the course, you should not be in the Piazza.
the principle is simple - the more helpers (experienced) we have to answer questions on Piazza, the better. If the responses are incorrect, anyone is welcome to update it.

On the surface, it seems like non-course volunteers contribute to the course. After all, more Piazza questions get answered! However, students and course staff actually learn LESS.

 

If a question has already been answered fully, are you going to repeat the same thing? No. And that process of answering other people's questions is crucial for TAs and students alike to fill in gaps in their understanding.

 

If you are not in the course, you should not be in the Piazza. The Piazza is not for you. Period.
Steven Bi is a valuable resource.

We already are paying people to teach us, they're called TAs and professors.

If Steven Bi wants to become a TA (I know he already was one), then I would love to see him active on Piazza.

However, since he's not a part of the course at all, he needs to please stop.
I think you need to explain your logic so we can follow up or else this does not quite make sense to me.
The principle is simple - if you are not in the course, you should not be in the Piazza.

Anon, I also have a simple principle - if you can answer a question on a course Piazza, you should answer it. 

Now, we have two principles, neither of which is substantiated. Which ought win?

You are making ill-posed appeals to teleology that don't address the reality of students' experiences. Sometimes questions linger unanswered indefinitely. Would it be better to allow such uncertainty to continue, or to - shock and horror - let somebody who is not enrolled in the course nor a TA answer it?

@Anon: "The principle is simple - if you are not in the course, you should not be in the Piazza."

There is absolutely no basis for this claim. The course Piazza is up for moderation by the instructors of the course, and if they deem someone distracting, they can ban him/her. That they have not done so for Steven Bi and other answerers is because these people are invaluable resources that lessen the unanswered load on Piazza. If anyone really felt he was diminishing the learning experience, they would have banned him already, but he's not. In each class I've taken where he's been on the piazza (70/170/188), he's been an invaluable resource to every single student there in answering questions about the course. Not everyone that reads a question will know how to answer it, and not everyone that knows how to answer it will, leaving some questions completely unanswered and with larger gaps in student understanding than if Steven answered a question instead of the Student responders.

tl;dr: if it was a problem the instructors would have banned him already. He's been a godsend for most TAs and students alike.

1. Why hasn't Steven Bi been banned yet? I don't know. I think he is an incredibly helpful person. However, if he is a non-course volunteer, going forward he will certainly be banned. You can't expect course staff to enforce @5915 before it was even announced.

2. There is basis for the claim. Who is Piazza for? The students and course staff. It is simple logic. Non-course people should not be lurking around on Piazza. One professor I had called this academic dishonesty, in fact. They should do whatever other work they have, instead.
hahahaha did you just cite your own piazza post as a justification for your own piazza post? L E G E N D A R Y

@staff Please ban "Thomas Liao".


He is a troll.
If anything we should be paying Steven Bi

I agree.

Whoever did that was wrong.

However, I must admit, this is a staff level announcement. From now onwards, "non-course volunteers" are banned in course Piazzas.
Ok, this recent Anon is obviously trolling, so I sincerely hope they aren't the OP.
It's not ideal, but perhaps the staff needs to ban anonymous posting now that this piazza is mostly unmoderated.
they already have
I'd really like to know how and why all the posts became anonymous as soon as I said maybe nobody should be anonymous anymore.

Someone said in the student answer this is the battle of the trolls - thomas liao and OP.

Thomas Liao then made all his comments anonymous
No, everyone's comments were made anonymous all at once. Including mine.
That's strange...I don't see you as anonymous
I only see 4 non-anonymous comments in this entire post, not including this one. Is that not what you see?

And when I say my previous comments are anonymous, I mean it's like they aren't even my comments anymore. I can't edit them, and if I remember correctly when you post anonymously you can still see some indication that the post was yours.
This shouldn't be pinned. Only staff announcements are supposed to be pinned.

@5971 is not a valid Piazza post.

Thomas Liao, stop trolling. Remember @5842?
Thanks for unpinning.

And I don't mean to be personal against you, it's just that I was kind of offended by your behavior in @5842 and I don't want this thread to be hijacked by trolls either.

If I was out of line then I apologize
Please stop pinning this item. Pins are only for departmental posts.

history.content:
I've noticed several course "volunteers" who are in many CS Piazzas. However, they are not students or in the course staff at all. Many of them have already graduated.

I think this has gone a little too far. I know they're trying to help out, and I am really glad for that - don't get me wrong.

But Piazza is a place for members of a course to discuss. If someone is not in the course, and he is answering questions, then fewer people in the course are participating in the discussions, diminishing students' learning experience.

Volunteers are really helpful in EECS 101. But let's ban them in course Piazzas, for everyone's learning.
history.subject: "Volunteers" in course Piazzas are banned, for the sake of learning

I think this has gone a little too far. I know they're trying to help out, and I am really glad for that - don't get me wrong.

But Piazza is a place for members of a course to discuss. If someone is not in the course, and he is answering questions, then fewer people in the course are participating in the discussions, diminishing students' learning experience.

Volunteers are really helpful in EECS 101. But let's ban them in course Piazzas, for everyone's learning.

#pin

history.content:
I've noticed several course "volunteers" who are in many CS Piazzas. However, they are not students or in the course staff at all. Many of them have already graduated. Probably the best-known is Steven Bi.

I think this has gone a little too far. I know they're trying to help out, and I am really glad for that - don't get me wrong.

But Piazza is a place for members of a course to discuss. If someone is not in the course, and he is answering questions, then fewer people in the course are participating in the discussions, diminishing students' learning experience.

Also, CS courses have enough staff to answer questions on Piazza. No need to make volunteers do the work :)

Volunteers are really helpful in EECS 101 but let's ban it in course Piazzas, for everyone's learning. Thanks for your time!!
history.subject: Let's avoid non-course "volunteers" in course Piazzas.

Volunteers are really helpful in EECS 101 but let's ban it in course Piazzas, for everyone's learning. Thanks!!
history.subject: Let's avoid non-course "volunteers" in course Piazzas.

history.content:
I've noticed several course "volunteers" who are in many CS Piazzas. However, they are not students or in the course staff at all. Many of them have already graduated. Probably the best-known is Steven Bi.

I think this has gone a little too far. I know they're trying to help out, and I am really glad for that - don't get me wrong.

But Piazza is a place for course students, staff, and tutors to discuss. If someone outside the class, no matter who, is answering many of the questions, then fewer students and course staff are, and it's diminishing students' learning experience.

Volunteers are really helpful in EECS 101 but let's ban it in course Piazzas, for everyone's learning :)

history.subject: Let's avoid non-course members in course Piazzas.

history.content:
I see Steven Bi and a few others as "endorsed student answerers" on Piazza.

1. What does that mean? How do they compare to peer advisors?

2. Also, who is Steven Bi, and why is he in every Piazza? I know he's trying to help out, and I am really glad for that - don't get me wrong. But Piazza is a place for course students, staff, and tutors to discuss. If someone outside the class, no matter who, is answering all the questions, then fewer students and course staff are, and it's diminishing their learning experience.

Volunteers are really helpful in EECS 101 but let's keep it down in course Piazzas. Again, nothing but respect for volunteers on EECS 101.

history.subject: Who are these endorsed student answerers?

history.content:
I see Steven Bi and a few others as "endorsed student answerers" on Piazza.

1. What does that mean? How do they compare to peer advisors?

2. Also, who is Steven Bi? Why is he in every Piazza? I know he's trying to help out, and I am really glad for that - don't get me wrong. But Piazza is a place for course students, staff, and tutors to discuss, and if someone outside the class is giving answers, that is usually counterproductive.

Again, no offense meant at all!
history.subject: Who are these endorsed student answerers?
